chunks.text: Bees are clever builders. The six-sided cells of the honeycomb
combined strength with economy of materials. That's why Mr. Brutzer New Plymouth beekeeper
believes man can learn from bees. It's not just a bee in his bonnet for when he
wasn't with his bees he built himself a house on the honeycomb pattern. Claiming he's taken the sting out of building he's in clover when visitors want to know how.
Using unconventional building methods called for a lot of ingenuity, and Mr. Bruce is no drone when thinking up new ways to swing a door.
Instead of wallpaper, panelling of different woods such as honeysuckle builds up and repeats the honeycomb patterns.
Yes, even the switchboard. There's probably not another that shape in New Zealand.
Some admiring friends completed the bedroom with this handmade patchwork quilt.
As everywhere it shows the influence of the bee and the hexagonal. Well almost everywhere, a grandfather clock adds something old to something new.
Mrs. Brewster tells visitors what housekeeping is like in a house where a square is rare.
Strangely enough by using prefabricated parts the house is cheaper to build than a conventional one.

You may drive because it's your business.
You may drive because it's your pleasure.
Or you may drive because, well anyway, no matter why you drive, you use the road.
You and 750,000 other drivers.
The people who use the roads pay for them.
The tax on every gallon of petrol that's bought is earmarked for the National Road Board,
the state organization that looks after our highways and byways.
You pay the board and with your money it builds you a better road. 55
million pounds worth in the last three years.
The cities are growing very fast and that means traffic congestion is growing very bad.
New motorways from the cities have to be built and old ones wider. For example, Auckland's northern motorway is being extended to cope with
little Sydney's rush our traffic. Getting from town to town can be a problem
too so from Dargaville to the bluff new roads are being built across the land. The
Nelson to Fixon Highway typifies roads that are planned to carry a heavy traffic
flow.
West of Nelson, another highway is going out towards Murchison.
Three years ago, back country roads were really bad.
Though a number are still in poor condition, an enormous amount of work like this job at Waihee
is being done to take the potholes out of Sunday driving.
Wirewecker Gorge, Gisbon's main road west.
Through this twisting country, construction of a new road has been going on for some time.

In the not too distant future, Gisbon will be solidly linked with inland centers. In the gorge, the work of blasting and clearing, blasting and clearing again, is bringing a new road out towards Gisner.
But it's not only new highways that are being pushed along.
Existing main roads all over the country are being widened and resurfaced.
When operations are finished between Rotorua and Pocateani, the road will be 16 feet wider.
Road widening means re-sealing and that's something else the motorists can be thankful
for.
Dusty backblock roads may be picturesque, but they aren't comfortable to drive off.
The East Coast route in the South Island was once a store point with motorists.
This year you can drive from Blenheim to the Bluff on sealed highway.
No road can go very far without running into a river, or rather over a river.
New bridges like this one in the King Country go up as the roads go down.
In eight months' time, the old Waterloo Bridge at Akatio will be replaced.
Down south, one of the longest bridges being built will span the Weirau River, not far from Blenheim.
Another job in the North Island is bridging the Mangauly River.
New bridges, new surfacing and new roads.
Over the length and breadth of New Zealand the construction gangsaoni River. New bridges, new surfacing and new roads. Over the length and breadth
of New Zealand the construction gangs are at work. Communication and transport services
have speeded up and things made easier for all of us to use the road. Now that's over,
you two can stop it and go home.
Ru'a Pahu, the white roof of the North Island, once revered by the Maris as a god, became the playground of our pioneer skiers.
This handful of hardy New Zealanders toiled up the slopes with only the promise of the downward run to ease their aching musk.
Skiing was for the fit, the energetic, the fuel.
But we're moving with the time.
The landscape's changing.
We've mechanized the mountain and taken the drudgery out of climbing.
And today, thousands of skiers come to Rorpeu to leave for a time the traffic and congestion of the city.
To get away from the daily routine, the morning bus to catch,
the parking space to find.
Here they're free from the unexpected bumps and
knocks of life in the town. They come to relax, leaving their chores behind them.
Thousands of feet above the dull gray day of winter, it's holiday weather, so
everybody settles down to work. A few sit first and figure out how to start.
Some take a little time to regain last year's form.
Some go to school and learn the three hours, rhythm,
relaxation and recumbents.
While others, just like to make things difficult for themselves.
In the quiet stillness of the valleys,
skiers are taken by the scruff of the pants and wafed up into the sky.
So different from the old days when getting up the mountain took so much time.
But in the past, you were so busy looking where you were going, you had little time
to appreciate where you were going and the view.
Today, skiers travel by air with a generous baggage allowance.
The service is excellent.
Tilled fruit juice follows an airborne breakfast. The lift takes gears up to the top floor.
Top floor, cosmetic, ladies millinery, cafeteria.
Here they prepare for the run down.
Except those who tried it once and didn't like it.
They remain seated and go sightseeing again. down. Except those who tried it once and didn't like it, they remain seatless and
go sightseeing again. But the rest swing down the valleys, tasting the
exhilaration of one of the most exciting sports in the world on the long runs
made accessible today by the lifts and toes.
We've mechanized the mountain.
Ruofihu lifted old white head stoically to the sky as he reflects that his ancient stronghold has been turned upside down.
